Modified-Alt-Text:
Graph of exposure wavelength versus resolution range.
Line is drawn from the G line to the immersion points, and then down to the EUV and DP (double patterning) line.
The x-axis, marked as the resolution range (measured in nanometers), spans from 10,000 nm down to 1 nm, while the y-axis, denoting exposure wavelength (also measured in nanometers), ranges from 8 nm up to 800 nm.
Over time, the industry has progressively shifted from the G Line at approximately 436 nm, through i-Line at 365 nm, to various forms of deep ultraviolet (DUV) lithography.
Immersive and dry techniques utilizing KrF (248 nm) and ArF (193 nm) wavelengths have pushed the boundaries of minimum feature size downwards.
As these methods approached their limits, immersion lithography emerged around these wavelengths, further enhancing resolution by changing the medium between the lens and wafer to water, consequently increasing the effective numerical aperture.
A compelling deviation occurs when the graph dives steeply towards the left as it transitions from ArF immersion to extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography, which employs a significantly lower wavelength of 13.5 nm.
However, moving into the EUV regime demanded overcoming extensive technical hurdles related to light source power, optical system precision, photoresist sensitivity, and mask defectivity.
Numerical aperture indicates how tightly the optics can focus light.

The electromagnetic spectrum is depicted, showing the range of electromagnetic waves from long-wavelength, low-frequency radio waves to short-wavelength, high-frequency gamma rays, with a visible light region highlighted in the center.
Both axes are logarithmically scaled to accommodate the broad range from long waves with frequencies around 10^3 Hz and wavelengths upwards of 10^6 meters, to gamma rays with frequencies as high as 10^24 Hz and wavelengths down to 10^-15 meters.
Within this framework, various bands are identified, including radio waves (long waves and AM (amplitude modulation)/FM/TV), microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.
Analyzing the interactions, the inverse relationship between wavelength and frequency is crucial for understanding electromagnetic wave behaviors.
For instance, long radio waves possess lower frequencies and correspondingly larger wavelengths, facilitating long-distance communication by diffracting around obstacles.
Conversely, gamma rays, characterized by extremely short wavelengths and high frequencies, are highly energetic and capable of penetrating most materials, making them useful in medical imaging yet hazardous due to their ionizing radiation.
A peculiar observation within the spectrum is the relatively narrow band of visible light (approximately 4 x 10^14 to 8 x 10^14 Hz or 400 nm to 700 nm wavelength) that signifies the range perceivable by the human eye.
This band, nestled within a minuscule fraction of the entire spectrum, stands out because of its biological significance and the way it demarcates the boundaries between non-ionizing and ionizing radiation.

A detailed schematic representation of an Extreme Ultraviolet (EUV) Lithography Exposure System, illustrating its components and functionality. The diagram is segmented into various parts, clearly labeled to indicate their roles. It features a reflective mask, EUV source collector, and illuminator optics, all aligned to focus EUV radiation onto a silicon wafer, specifically stated to be 300 mm in diameter. The system operates using 13.5 nm radiation, which is crucial for achieving high-resolution patterns necessary for advanced semiconductor manufacturing. Key annotations highlight that the optics are entirely reflective and that the entire optical pathway functions within a vacuum environment to prevent interference and ensure accuracy. The organization of this exposure system emphasizes the integration of precise optics in lithography.

The graph displays the cumulative shift of pulsar-orbital time in seconds on the vertical axis against the year on the horizontal axis, ranging from 1975 to 2005. The data points are marked with error bars and follow a smooth, downward-curving line, illustrating a trend of increasing negative cumulative shift over time. The line labeled "General Relativity prediction" closely follows the data points, indicating consistency between observed orbital decay and theoretical predictions. The "Line of zero orbital decay" is displayed above the data points and prediction line, delineating the lack of orbital decay. The primary finding is that the observed data aligns well with the General Relativity prediction, reinforcing the theory's validity in describing the decay of orbits over time.

Diagram shows five 2?D crystal lattice (Bravais) types as unit cells with lattice vectors a1 and a2 and the angle ? between them. Each cell also marks its symmetry (mirror lines and rotation axes). Here, an �n?fold rotation� means the pattern looks the same after a rotation of 360�/n. Oblique: a1 and a2 at an arbitrary angle (no right angles), with the least symmetry. Rectangular: a1 ? a2 (right angles) with 2?fold rotation symmetry. Centered rectangular: rectangular cell with an extra lattice point at the center, giving additional symmetry compared to simple rectangular. Square: equal sides with 4?fold rotation symmetry (invariant under 90� turns). Hexagonal: a1 and a2 at 60�/120� with 6?fold rotation symmetry.

The illustration presents varieties of crystal lattice structures: cubic body-centered (bcc (body-centered cubic)), cubic face-centered (fcc (face-centered cubic)), and hexagonal.
Each structure is characterized by a distinct arrangement of atoms, represented by spheres, and the connecting lines indicate bonds within the lattice.
The bcc structure features atoms at each corner of a cube and an additional atom at the center of the cube.
This configuration, common in elements such as iron (Fe), vanadium (V), niobium (Nb), and chromium (Cr), allows for efficient packing density and significant metallic bonding interactions, particularly enhancing its structural strength.
In contrast, the fcc structure places atoms at each cube corner and at the centers of each cube face, known for its close-packed nature.
Metals such as aluminum (Al), nickel (Ni), silver (Ag), copper (Cu), and gold (Au) often crystallize in this form.
The fcc structure provides even greater packing efficiency and is associated with superior ductility and conductivity, attributed to the dense atomic arrangement which allows atoms to slide past each other more easily under stress.
The hexagonal lattice, depicted with atoms at each corner of the hexagonal base and additional ones inside the volume, is prevalent in materials like titanium (Ti), zinc (Zn), magnesium (Mg), and cadmium (Cd).
This hexagonal close-packed (hcp) structure promotes a coordination number of twelve, emphasizing close atomic packing and resulting in high strength but less ductility compared to the fcc.

Two rays hitting different planes at the same angle. They arrive parallel and reflect parallel. The path difference is equal to 2 multiplied by D multiplied by sin(theta) where D is the distance between planes.

The illustration depicts a conceptual representation of electromagnetic induction. At the center, a circular loop is shown, marked with a blue line that outlines its shape. Arrows pointing upward denote an increasing magnetic field, labeled as ??(??), suggesting a change over time. A small positive and negative sign indicates electrical polarity, while a zigzag line represents a resistor connected to the loop. An arrow on one side illustrates the direction of induced current, labeled ??, which flows in response to the changing magnetic field, and another arrow indicates the resultant induced magnetic field ??.

The diagram illustrates a fundamental concept in electromagnetism, showcasing a magnetic field generated between a north (N) and a south (S) pole of a magnet, positioned adjacent to two conductive plates. The key elements include the orientation of the magnetic field lines that curve around the magnet, indicating the direction of magnetic flux, and the representation of the angle ??, which signifies its relationship to the distance ?? from the plates. The circuit connected to the magnet suggests a scenario where variations in the magnetic field could induce an electric current. The use of blue shading likely denotes areas of magnetic influence or the presence of a magnetic field, while the arrows imply the direction of force or flow. This configuration reveals the principles of electromagnetic induction, highlighting how changes in magnetic fields can affect electrically conductive materials.

The diagram illustrates the principles of electromagnetic force acting on a current-carrying conductor within a magnetic field. Key elements include a resistor labeled 'R,' a current 'I' flowing through the conductor indicated by an arrow, and a magnetic field 'B' represented with circles and crosses indicating field direction. Axes are marked along the horizontal (x) and vertical (y) dimensions, with relevant symbols showing the flow of current and the resulting magnetic force 'F_m' acting on the conductor. The interrelationship between current and magnetic fields is emphasized, highlighting the dynamics of forces involved when a conductor moves with velocity 'u' in the magnetic field. This representation elucidates the foundational concept of electromagnetism, demonstrating how electric currents interact with magnetic fields to produce motion.

The radius of the loop is marked as ????=10cm. An arrow within the loop indicates the direction of current ??1(??), suggesting the variable nature of the current over time. On the left side, a circuit having a voltage source 'V' and resistor 'R'. On the right side, a toroid wrapped with current carrying 'N' turns. The voltage 'V' and current 'I' of an electric circuit are equivalent to Magneto motive force 'F' and magnetic flux 'shi' of a magnetic circuit, respectively.

The diagram displays a representation of a helical structure, characterized by a series of spiraling lines that denote magnetic field lines, illustrated in black, along a central axis depicted in green. The helical lines are numbered sequentially from 1 to N, suggesting multiple loops or windings around the axis. Key equations are presented in green text, where ??=????? signifies a relationship involving magnetic flux and surface area, while ??=???? indicates a dependence on the number of loops. The diagram emphasizes the geometrical and physical relationships governing helical magnetic fields, underscoring the interplay between intensity and field configuration.

A toroid has current carrying conductors in both inner and outer radius. The current (marked in red) is flowing into the page for the conductors at outer radius. The current is flowing out of the page for the conductors at the inner radius. The magnetic field 'B' (marked in green) is flowing inside the toroid in anti-clockwise direction.

This diagram illustrates the arrangement of a conducting medium with elements represented in a 3D coordinate system. The horizontal axis (w) signifies the width of the conductive sections, while the vertical axis (h) represents their height, and the z-axis points upward. The boxes, marked in red, indicate regions where electric currents (I) flow, with the direction of the current denoted by arrows. The green circles and crosses symbolize the distribution of charge carriers within the conductive material, likely indicating the movement of electrons. Additionally, the presence of a magnetic field (B) is highlighted, implying interactions between the current and the field.

The diagram illustrates a helical coil, showing its structure in a three-dimensional perspective.
Key elements include the dimensions labeled as ?? for diameter and ?? indicating the axial direction, indicating how the coil extends in space.
There are also markings for ?? representing the number of turns, and ?? defined as the pitch, which is the distance between successive turns.
The light blue color of the coil emphasizes its three-dimensionality and spiraling form.

The illustration presents two distinct scenarios related to electromagnetic fields and their behavior concerning closed surfaces. On the left, the diagram represents the electric field around a positive charge (+Q), signifying that the net electric flux through the closed surface is equal to the total charge enclosed, as indicated by the expression ? = Q. The field lines emanate outward from the charge, clearly showing the directional flow and density of the electric field. On the right, the illustration depicts a magnetic field around a closed surface with no enclosed magnetic charge (N and S denote a magnetic dipole), where the net magnetic flux is represented as ? = 0, indicating that magnetic field lines do not start or end within the surface. Both diagrams utilize arrows to communicate the direction of field lines, emphasizing the divergence of electric fields and the absence of magnetic monopoles.

The horizontal ground on which the weightlifter stands is labeled �y equals 0.� The motion of barbell lift at three positions is shown. In the final position, the barbell is right above the lifter�s head with arms fully extended vertically. In this position, two arrows point from the center of the barbell: vector F subscript weightlifter points vertically upward along the vertical axis, and vector w equals vector F subscript gravity points vertically downward, also along the vertical axis. The vertical distance between the ground and the bottom of the barbell is h.

Two opposite poles of two different magnets are placed near to each other. The magnetic flux density 'B' (marked in green) is coming out of north pole and entering into the south pole. There is conductor in between the opposite magnetic pole, carrying a current 'I' (marked in red). The magnetic force 'Fm' is acting downward, perpendicular to the magnetic flux density.
Two current flowing loops (indicated as '1' and '2') are placed closely. A vector line 'R21' is connecting two differential elements from these two separate loops.

On left side, a rectangular loop carrying a current 'I' in the magnetic flux density 'B' (marked in blue). The length and width of the rectangular loop are 'L' and 'W', respectively. On right side, the width of the rectangular loop is at an angle with the magnetic flux density 'B' (marked in blue). The forces are acting perpendicular to the flux density 'B'.

The image represents a three-dimensional coordinate system illustrating spherical coordinates, characterized by the radius ??, polar angle ??, and azimuthal angle ??. Key axes are labeled: the x-axis extends horizontally, the y-axis is perpendicular to it, and the z-axis extends vertically. A circular shape, marked in blue, signifies the plane where the angles ?? and ?? are defined, while dashed lines represent the projection of these coordinates onto the respective axes. This system emphasizes the relationship between the spherical coordinates and their Cartesian counterparts, highlighting how points in space can be described through varying combinations of ??, ??, and ??.

Nine panels (a�i) illustrate one full cycle of simple harmonic motion for a horizontal spring�block system. A block on the right is attached to a spring fixed to a wall on the left. A horizontal position line is labeled x = ?A, x = 0 (equilibrium), and x = +A. Long arrows represent the larger?magnitude vector and short arrows the smaller?magnitude vector; arrows are labeled for spring force F and velocity v.
Stage 1 (starting stretched at +A): v = 0 at the turning point; the spring force points left (toward equilibrium). The block accelerates left.
Stage 2 (moving toward equilibrium): as x approaches 0, the restoring force decreases in magnitude while speed increases; at x = 0, F = 0 and v is maximum.
Stage 3 (compressed at ?A): v = 0 at the opposite turning point; the spring force points right. The block accelerates right back toward equilibrium.
Stage 4 (returning): the pattern repeats as it passes x = 0 again (v maximum, F = 0) and returns to x = +A.

A magnet bar is placed in a magnetic field density 'B' (marked in blue). Two forces are acting on opposite direction at two poles of the magnet bar. The torque is trying to align the bar in the direction of the applied magnetic field.

Table/diagram relates quantum numbers to orbital shapes. Rows group orbitals by principal quantum number n and orbital type l (s, p, d, f, g). Columns correspond to different |m?| values, showing how orbitals of the same type can differ mainly by orientation.
Key patterns: s orbitals (l = 0, m? = 0) are spherical with no angular nodes. p orbitals (l = 1) are two?lobed (�dumbbell�) with one nodal plane; different m? values correspond to different orientations. d orbitals (l = 2) are four?lobed (or a two?lobed shape with a torus), with two angular nodes; f and g orbitals show progressively more lobes and nodal surfaces as l increases. As n increases (down the table), orbitals of the same l become larger and may show additional radial nodes (shells) in the probability density.

On left side, magnetic dipoles, in small volume, with scattered direction when no external magnetic field is applied. That means B equals 0. On right side, magnetic dipoles, in small volume, oriented in the same direction as applied magnetic field 'B'.

The angle ?? is marked, suggesting the orientation between the two vectors.
On the right, a conical surface visually represents the magnitude of the cross product as the area of the parallelogram formed by A and B, with the same vectors and their resultant indicated.
The primary implication is the use of the right-hand rule and visualization of the cross product.
S-shape microstrip patch antenna radiating EM waves, where electric field is orthogonal to magnetic field. The direction of wave propagation is also perpendicular to both fields.

The image illustrates three distinct vector field representations centered around point P, showcasing different directional behaviors. The leftmost configuration reveals a radiating pattern, where arrows emanate outward from P, indicating a source-like behavior, typically associated with positive charge or outward forces. The middle arrangement presents an inward-directed flow, with arrows converging towards P, representing a sink-like behavior, indicative of negative charge or attractive forces. The rightmost depiction shows parallel arrows that suggest a uniform flow, indicating constant vector magnitude and direction without variation in intensity.

The graph illustrates trends in functional CPU scaling over time, spanning from 2008 to 2030, with a logarithmic representation of performance on the vertical axis labeled as "Log (Functional CPU Scaling)" and the horizontal axis denoting "Year of 1st Production." Key elements include various curves indicating different strategies for improving CPU performance, such as Design Technology Co-Optimization (DTCO) and System Technology Co-Optimization (STCO). Notable milestones are marked with specific technologies and their introduction years, including terms like "14nm" and "7nm," showcasing significant milestones in CPU technology development. The green line represents Design Technology Co-Optimization, indicating its role in offsetting the slower gains in performance often associated with scaling down transistor sizes. The overall trend suggests a gradual but steady improvement in CPU scaling, highlighting ongoing innovations aimed at overcoming challenges in semiconductor manufacturing.

The chart illustrates the evolution of semiconductor manufacturing processes from 1970 to 2020, focusing on key metrics such as node sizes and wafer dimensions. The y-axis represents feature sizes in microns, ranging from 0.01 to 10 microns, while the x-axis denotes the timeline from 1970 to 2020. Various colors differentiate elements: pink for node sizes, blue for wafer sizes, and green for de-magnification ratios, indicating the scaling of technology over decades. A notable downward trend visible on the chart showcases a consistent reduction in node size from 6.1 microns in 1970 to 13.5 nanometers (or 0.0135 microns) by 2020, reflecting significant advancements in fabrication technologies. The de-magnification ratios are also highlighted, showing a transition from 1:1 to 4:1, emphasizing the increasing complexity and precision required in semiconductor manufacturing. This data underscores the rapid technological progress and miniaturization within the industry, ultimately impacting performance, power efficiency, and scalability of electronic devices.

The image consists of two graphs representing spectral irradiance over different wavelength ranges, with both displaying spectral parts labeled accordingly. The left graph illustrates the spectral irradiance in nanometers, highlighting a sharp peak around the visible spectrum (approximately 400-700 nm) while tapering off towards the ultraviolet (UV) and infrared (IR) ends. The right graph features a broader spectral range, incorporating an expanded view from UV to near-infrared wavelengths, with color coding indicating different spectral regions such as UV, visible, and IR (including UVA and UVB). The dominant colors in the visible range create a vivid rainbow effect, emphasizing the intensity of solar irradiance at these wavelengths. Both graphs reveal a notable decrease in intensity beyond the visible spectrum, indicating a significant decline in spectral irradiance as it moves into the infrared and ultraviolet ranges, which has implications for understanding energy distribution and environmental impacts related to solar radiation.

The illustration features a series of stylized diagrams that represent the interaction between waves or particles as they transition through a medium. The leftmost section depicts waves propagating linearly, indicated by an arrow. As they reach a boundary in the middle, they appear to encounter resistance. The right section illustrates the resulting phenomena, with lines radiating outward to signify the scattering or diffusion of these waves into the surrounding environment. Key elements include the direction of wave travel, the imposition of a barrier, and the dispersal pattern that highlights changes in behavior upon interaction with different media.

The diagram illustrates a lithography process, focusing on the differences between two exposure scenarios represented on the left and right sides. It consists of five key layers: the mask pattern at the top, followed by representations of the near field and far field light distributions, intensity at resist, and the resulting transferred pattern. The mask pattern shows alternating regions of varying opacity, while the near and far field sections depict the light intensity variations through the use of solid and wavy lines, indicating differences in light behavior during exposure. Color plays a significant role, with orange and blue lines symbolizing different light fields, and green lines highlighting intensity variations at the resist. The transferred pattern at the bottom showcases the final outcome with distinguishable features that mimic the mask design. The primary finding illustrates how variations in exposure conditions can directly affect the quality and clarity of the transferred pattern, emphasizing the significance of optimizing lithographic processes in semiconductor fabrication.

The representation includes a series of diagrams illustrating a scientific process, complemented by a molecular structure and a histogram. The first diagram outlines a process involving multiple components, with labeled distances of 1 m and indications of particle interactions and behavior in a system under a voltage of about -10 kV. The second part showcases a molecular structure with various atoms depicted, relating to specific chemical groups. Lastly, a histogram presents frequency distribution against mass, with values ranging from 20,000 to 30,000 Da, indicating quantifiable data points in a series of peaks. These peaks suggest distinct mass distributions, likely representing different molecular species, highlighting variations in their abundance or stability.

The image presents a scatter plot with a distinct pattern depicting counts recorded over time against the detector position, measured in micrometers (�m). The x-axis is labeled "Detector position in �m," ranging from -150 to +150, while the y-axis indicates "Counts in 100 s," with values reaching up to 400. The data points, represented as grey dots, showcase a series of peaks and troughs, indicating fluctuations in counts as the detector position changes. Notably, there are pronounced peaks around the center, particularly at the position of 0 �m, suggesting a significant concentration of counts at this detector position, while several smaller peaks are also visible on either side, indicating secondary areas of interest. The overall trend demonstrates a clear periodicity, emphasizing areas of higher detection efficacy, which may imply underlying physical phenomena or interactions being measured.

The representation showcases a scatter plot with a smooth curve fitted through the data points. The x-axis is labeled "Transverse displacement (nm)," ranging from 0 to 1,000 nanometers, while the y-axis is marked "Norm counts," extending up to 1.5. Blue dots indicate individual data points, highlighting their distribution along the curve. The black line illustrates a sinusoidal trend, revealing periodic fluctuations in normalized counts in response to varying transverse displacements. The primary finding indicates a consistent oscillatory pattern, suggesting a relationship between displacement and counts that could be significant in understanding underlying physical phenomena.

This scatter plot illustrates the relationship between the year and a metric labeled "Macroscopicity," with the years ranging from 1980 to 2020 on the x-axis and values of Macroscopicity from 5 to 15 on the y-axis. Different shapes and colors represent distinct categories or groups, such as blue crosses, green circles, purple squares, and a red diamond, each indicating specific data points related to the time frame. The trend suggests a gradual increase in Macroscopicity over the years, particularly noticeable after 2000, where several points cluster at higher values. The overall implication emphasizes a positive trajectory in Macroscopicity, suggesting advancements or changes in the underlying subject matter over the decades.

Multi?panel figure (a�e) compares how different laser beam phase/wavefront configurations change the interference (intensity) pattern inside a structured medium (e.g., a photonic crystal). Each panel shows an input wavefront (with propagation direction arrows labeled kx and kz), the medium region, and the resulting intensity/interference pattern.
Overall trend: changing the input wavefront (tilt, phase ramp, or curvature) changes where constructive and destructive interference occur�seen as shifts in fringe orientation, spacing, and symmetry. Panel (a) shows a cross?like interference pattern. Panels (b�e) show variants with more linear (stripe?like) fringes versus more radial/curved patterns, indicating that a linear phase variation produces approximately parallel fringes, while a radial/curved phase produces more circular or curved interference features. The comparison is meant to connect �how the beam is shaped� to �how the intensity distributes� in the medium.

The illustration presents a series of horizontal lines representing a specific crystallographic orientation, labeled as the {10} orientation. Each line is populated with evenly spaced dots, which denote atomic or molecular positions within the crystal lattice. A key measurement, denoted by "D," is indicated between two of the lines, suggesting a relevant distance or spacing between the different layers of the lattice. This spacing is crucial for understanding material properties like density and strength. The arrangement highlights the uniformity and periodic nature of the crystalline structure, which is vital for applications in materials science and engineering. The visual representation allows for a quick grasp of the spatial relationships between various components of the crystalline framework.

The blue curve for ????1 is a monotonically increasing function, starting from near zero at ??/????=0 and approaching a value close to 0.5 as ??/???? increases, indicating a relatively moderate response to temperature changes. In contrast, the red curve for ????2 exhibits a decreasing trend, starting at 1 and dropping significantly as the temperature ratio increases. The intersection of these curves would provide key insights into the critical conditions influencing the system's behavior.
STM (scanning tunneling microscopy) Image of NbSe^2, 1 T, 1.8K. Scale is 6000 Angstroms and the atoms are arranged equally spaced out.
As the electron count is increased from 20 to 4000, the diffraction pattern is more clearly seen.

The diagram illustrates a double-slit experimental setup used in wave and quantum mechanics, emphasizing the interaction of incoming waves as they pass through two slits on a screen. Key elements include the vertical axis marked as "z," which indicates the position of a detector, and a horizontal segment labeled "L," representing the distance from the screen to the detector. The angle ? is depicted, suggesting the relationship between the path length variations due to the slits. The incoming waves are represented on the left side as a series of parallel lines, indicating wavefronts. This setup is essential for demonstrating interference patterns, revealing fundamental principles about wave-particle duality and the behavior of light and matter. The spatial relationship and indicated angles suggest that as the distance from the slits increases, the observed patterns will change.

The representation consists of two waveforms plotted against a horizontal axis labeled "Position" ranging from 0 to 10, with the vertical axis labeled "y" indicating amplitude. The top waveform is drawn in red, depicting a sinusoidal pattern with an amplitude (A) of 1 and a wavelength (?) of 1.2, while the bottom waveform, shown in black, also has an amplitude (A) of 1 but with a shorter wavelength (?) of 1.0. The prominent detail is the frequency of oscillation, where the top graph exhibits wider spacing between peaks compared to the tighter oscillations seen in the lower graph, indicating that as the wavelength decreases, the frequency of the wave increases. The contrasting colors enhance the visual distinction between the two graphs, emphasizing the effect of varying wavelengths on the sinusoidal pattern. The primary finding illustrates how wavelength influences the spatial frequency of wave phenomena.

The depiction consists of the two line graphs representing mathematical functions over a common horizontal axis labeled "Position" ranging from 0 to 10. The top graph features a blue sine wave oscillating between 0 and 2, displaying a consistent periodic pattern. Below, the second graph presents a more complex interplay of two functions: a red sine curve and a black sine curve, both of which oscillate out of phase with respect to one another. The vertical axis in both graphs is labeled "Sum," indicating the resultant values derived from the equations plotted. Notably, the patterns in the lower graph illustrate constructive and destructive interference, underscoring the dynamic relationship between the two waves. This visual representation emphasizes the principles of wave behavior and superposition, illustrating how overlapping waves can create varied amplitudes and frequencies.

The graph illustrates a mathematical function representing wave amplitudes relative to wave numbers. The x-axis, labeled "Wave number, k," spans from 0 to 1.4, while the y-axis, marked "Individual Wave Amplitude," ranges from 0 to 1. The curve, depicted in black, rises sharply to a peak at around k = 1 and subsequently declines, showing a Gaussian distribution centered at this value. Data points are indicated with solid black dots, aligning closely with the curve, emphasizing the function's accuracy in representing wave behavior. The equation ??(??)=???100(???1)2/2 suggests a strong concentration of wave amplitude around k = 1, highlighting its significance in the context of wave dynamics.
